Incorporate gamification elements: Incorporating game-like elements in the course can help make it more engaging and interactive. For example, students can earn badges or points for completing certain tasks or modules, which can motivate them to continue learning.

Personalized learning paths: Allow students to choose their own learning paths based on their interests and strengths. This can be done through adaptive learning technology that adjusts the course content and difficulty level based on the student's performance.

Interactive video lessons: Use interactive video lessons that allow students to participate in the learning process. For example, students can click on different parts of the video to see additional information or examples.

Collaborative learning: Encourage collaboration between students by incorporating group projects and discussions. This can help students learn from each other and develop their communication and teamwork skills.

Virtual reality simulations: Use virtual reality simulations to provide students with a more immersive learning experience. For example, students can practice real-world scenarios in a safe and controlled environment.
